Award.AwardTitle: The Alutiq Language Archive and Speaker Registry

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
A fundamental mission of the Documenting Endangered Language Program is to create digital infrastructure that provides scientists and endangered-language community members access to threatened language data. Countless extant records of endangered languages worldwide are in need of curation with input from linguists and the speaker-communities. April Counceller and Alisha Drabek of the Alutiiq Heritage Foundation will work with a strong team of community members, linguists, archivists, and museum curators to build a comprehensive database of one highly endangered language, Kodiak Alutiiq spoken in coastal Alaska (Alaska Peninsula to Prince William Sound). This database will include existing audio recordings with enhanced metadata, additional data from 33 remaining speakers, and a speaker registry recording when and how each speaker acquired the language. A major part of the project will be to educate Alutiiq speakers on metadata terminology so that materials can continue to be curated and located with ease.

The key to improved language documentation and linguistic discovery is access to language data from a variety of genres, ages, and styles since each data sample provides a different view of language structure. The proposed Alutiq database, created using the innovative Mukurtu Content Management System for endangered language data, will be a model for other communities on how to create a rich corpus for linguistic analysis and community use and how to curate data. It will provide data access and search capabilities. The project will fill gaps in the database by recording missing genres or interaction-types from speakers. The database will be easily accessible through the Alutiiq Museum and the Alaska Native Language Archive websites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Naken-Natmen (From Where, To Where) project focused on improving researcher and community access to Alutiiq language resources. The project allowed the Alutiiq Museum to create a digital Alutiiq language archive and Alutiiq Speaker Registry, update the Kodiak Regional Alutiiq Language Strategic Plan, and locate and translate historical Alutiiq language text materials. The archive can be found online at languagearchive.alutiiqmuseum.org. The archive contains videos, audio recordings, and transcripts of numerous Alutiiq speakers. Recordings in the archive span from the 1960s to the present. Now that the online archive exists, recordings can be added to it as Alutiiq language projects continue in the Kodiak area.

The Alutiiq Speaker Registry is a centralized place where learners, researchers, or community members can find speakers. It is also a place where Alutiiq language speakers can proudly share their stories and expertise. The online speaker registry documents the name, age, residency, and dialect of fluent Alutiiq speakers. For many of these speakers, there is a ?speech sample? provided on the Language Archive that gives Alutiiq language learners the ability to hear the language spoken by fluent speakers. Names are still being added to the registry as new learners emerge, and as we learn about Alutiiq speakers who have moved off-island and beyond, or who have not been involved with Alutiiq language projects until now.

During the last year of the project, the Alutiiq Museum explored historic text documents that were created in the 1800s: a dictionary created in 1805 by Nikolai Rezanov, the first of its kind; hundreds of pages of Alutiiq language information documented by Alphonse Pinart between 1871 and 1872; and a vocabulary list compiled in 1882 by William Fisher. People can view these materials at the Koniag Cultural Library at the Alutiiq Museum. These texts contain valuable information about Alutiiq people, culture, and practices during the Russian and early-American periods of Kodiak?s history. For those who want to learn more about these periods in history, that information is now more accessible.
